JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . He was represented before the ORG by Mr W. Tomczyk , a lawyer practising in GPE .

On DATE the applicant , who had been a candidate for ORG , submitted a lustration declaration as required by LAW DATE on disclosing work for or service in the ORG ’s security services or collaboration with them DATE by persons exercising public functions ( ustawa o ujawnieniu pracy lub służby w organach bezpieczeństwa państwa lub współpracy z nimi w latach DATE osób pełniących funkcje publiczne – “ the DATE LAW ” ) . In the declaration he admitted that he had served ( pełnił służbę ) in the ORG ’s security services . In the explanatory “ B ” section of the declaration he stated that he had been a company commander in ORG ( PERSON NORP Wewnętrzna – “ the WSW ” ) .

Afterwards , ORG ( ORG PERSON ) published information that the applicant had served in the ORG ’s security services within the meaning of the CARDINAL LAW . The applicant was elected as a member of ORG .

On DATE ORG ( Sąd Apelacyjny ) decided to institute proceedings in the applicant ’s case on the ground that he had lied in his lustration declaration by stating that he had served in the WSW , whereas in reality he had secretly cooperated with this service .

On DATE ORG , acting as the firstinstance lustration court , found that the applicant had been an intentional and secret collaborator with the LAW and had therefore lied in his lustration declaration . The court established that in DATE , while serving in the army as a professional soldier , the applicant had been recruited as a secret collaborator with the military counter - intelligence service of the ORG . The applicant had thus lied in his declaration . He must have known that he had served as a commander of a platoon of ORG in PERSON ( PERSON ) and not the WSW .

The applicant lodged an appeal against the decision . He argued that he had admitted to having had ties with the security service – the ORG – but had mistakenly characterised the nature of his contacts as “ service ” . The applicant pointed to the lengthy period of time that had elapsed since the events in question and to the lack of clarity of the declaration , which he had had difficulties in filling out .

On DATE ORG , acting as the secondinstance lustration court , dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . The court reiterated that the purpose of the lustration declaration was to reflect the truth . The content of the declaration should be exhaustive and its form should comply with legal requirements . The court agreed with the firstinstance court that the applicant had denied having been an intentional and secret collaborator with the ORG , which had been the ORG ’s security service within the meaning of the law . Lastly , the court dismissed the applicant ’s assertion that he had committed a mistake while filling out the declaration . The court found that there had been no mistake as to the facts because the applicant had obviously known that his place of service was ORG and not the ORG . Nor could he claim that there had been a mistake as to the law , as it had been his duty to acquaint himself with LAW and the explanatory note on the declaration .
The applicant lodged a cassation appeal ( kasacja ) with ORG ( Sąd Najwyższy ) .

On DATE ORG dismissed the cassation appeal as manifestly ill - founded . ORG followed the lower ORG findings that the applicant had undoubtedly been an intentional and secret collaborator with the secret service , the WSW . This collaboration had nothing in common with the official contacts the applicant had had with the ORG while serving in the army , but had been a secret collaboration initiated by his signing a collaboration declaration . ORG reiterated that the purpose of LAW had also been to disclose the past of politicians , who in a democratic ORG should be transparent and whose past should be known . Finally , the court dismissed the applicant ’s allegations that the form of the declaration had been confusing or open to contradictory interpretations . As a consequence of this judgment of ORG , on DATE the applicant lost his seat in ORG .
The applicant ’s lawyer submitted that he had been notified of that decision on DATE .
The relevant domestic law and practice concerning lustration proceedings in GPE are set out in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of ORG v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , ORG DATE ... ) .
